body.p:
Is Elkins next in line?
Now that Robert Spence, Bob Ward and Frank Fellows have resigned under pressure from students, the next target is none other than the Big Man himself, Wilson Elkins. Though many individuals have been harboring a desire to see the retirement of our distinguished president, a col­ lective effort is now under way to publicize Elkins' 15-year record of un­ responsiveness to students and the mani­ fold problems of a growing University, He has done much for academics and much for the University’s image, but all too little for the raison d’etre of this institution--the students. Remember them? Elkins’ availability is legendary, his morality of another age and his public statements a mixture of John Wayne and Dwight Eisenhower with a little Spiro Agnew thrown into the melange. And with the federal vindication of the
Student Government Association’s year­ long declaration of institutional racism, further impetus has been marshalled behind those forces, anonymous for the time being, who will soon embark on a publicity campaign to expose Elkins’ uselessness here. Much of Elkins’ problem is not sub­ stantive, but a matter of style wiiich is irrelevant to the newness of modern life. In introducing Sen. Edmund Muskie last week, Elkins had the unfortunate grace to mention four times that the senator is a loser and that we are proud to have him speak here. Elkins noted that the length of an introduction is commensurate with the speaker’s dignity and stature. “But this introduction will be brief,” Elkins faux-pased. Perhaps Elkins, beset with all kinds of pressure from the student body, the
legislature and from bewildered parents, will And it quite appealing to resign and return to teaching, or take a government position. Certainly his attitudes fit right in with the Nixon non-administration. The pressures of health, too, must be catching up with him and that would be as convenient an excuse as necessary to get oat of the College Park loony bin. Whenever it is that Elkins leaves his beloved constituents he should remember that old presidents don’t die—they just lose their faculties. ♦ ♦ Speaking of presidents, the newest darling of the law’n’order crowd. Father Theodore Hesburgh of Notre Dame is reputed to have dented that the publish or perish syndrome exists at his campus. The way he put it, the problem is “Publish or back to the parish," Ho, ho.
